segments.text: I remember how my childhood floated by.
I only wish that I knew that poem that Miss Kenny said one children's day.
Backward turn, backward, old time of your flight.
Make me a child just for tonight.
I'd like so very much to remember and recall
Many of the happy hours of my childhood life spent along the mighty Perth and Alice.
To some people, it is just a trickle of water flowing down through the peaceful hills.
But to me and to others who live on it, it has been a revealing pleasure of life and nature.
in its best and its worst.
The most pleasant hours of my life have been spent along this river.
And I enjoy it.
It would be nice to say that when my day's work is done and I've met the call from the other side, I would be permitted
to put my feet down on the banks of the Perdomales.
I was born in 1905, about a mile from where Lyndon was born.
in much the same structure house.
The only difference in our house in Linden's, we had boxed up, or my father did, an end on the front porch and he had also boxed up the end on the north porch.
The end on the north porch is where my mother would do her washing and it was a

a pantry like things we kept our canned foods our dirty clothes basket and our washing tub and rug board and my mother used to soak her clothes at night in the tub in order that they wouldn't be so hard to wash the next day she'd always soak them overnight and then there's where she would in this little shed rooms where she soaked
And the little shed room out on the south porch was where my Uncle Jesse would always sleep.
He was a veteran of the Civil War, and he had a wooden leg.
He was a very accomplished musician.
And I can look back now and remember the beautiful stories that he would tell.

me of his childhood in georgia and then as he came to alabama and then on to texas i only wish that i had been a little more patient and listened a little closer but children don't think of those things at that time if it's something that interests them they'll listen if it isn't they're up and gone but black people always did

intrigued me and he would tell me about how they would go out in the cane patch and how they would sing and how he enjoyed singing with them and working with them and he said they were the best cooks in the world and I believe he must be right because they are good cooks.
I enjoyed every minute of my time with Uncle Jesse.
Of course, I know I was quite a little, well, scamp, as he called me one time.
I didn't know what scamp was, but my mother explained it to me.
But I would, my father had an old
A colleague of mine by the name of Tim McConaughey stayed and worked with us a lot of time.
And Tim says, now that Uncle Jesse stomps that wooden leg, gets at you and runs you through this house, you just start singing.
Donna's got a wooden leg laid away.
Donna's got a meat skin laid away.
Greaves that wooden leg twice a day.
And it had several verses to it.
It said, you'll get him stopped.
He won't teach you anymore.
But that didn't work.
Uncle Jesse would stomp that one leg and start out after me.
And I'll tell you, I made tracks down that trail.
I didn't waste any time.
But it was a pleasure of an afternoon.
We'd always have to go down and let the cow in from the pasture, which is about 200 yards from the house down a trail.
And oh, I don't know, seemed like the flowers then were so much brighter.
The colors were so much prettier.
And they were just naturally larger, seems to me.
I'm sure they were not, but that's the way it seems.

he would stop and tell me the name of every flower that we pass and he'd explain it to me and and you know that takes a lot of patience to fool with a kid like that but i but i learned to love flowers i learned to appreciate them
